Title: 'True Grit' Trailer HD
Comment: The Coens as a team are the modern day version of Alfred Hitchcock. This outstanding film is much more than a humdrum run-of-the-mill western, rich with unforgettable characters and the usual Coen idiosyncrasies. An American masterpiece equal to Fargo. The performance of 13 year old Hailee Steinfeld was worthy of Best Supporting Actress in that year's Oscars. Just think what this movie would have been like with any other performer. One of my favourite all time movies - a classic!.

Comment:
@ryanmacdaddy1000 

Yeah, what I mean is, how about the cottage and location where Moon dies?  In the films, it angles are almost identical, and you can't refer it to the book.  They had used that exact same location in "North to Alaska" years earlier.   The films can hardly be discerned from each other really.

Title: 'True Grit' Trailer HD
Comment: @porterwake the old one was shot in the Colorado Rockies, which are stunning don't get me wrong, but it doesn't do the story a whole lot of justice when it takes place somewhere else

Title: 'True Grit' Trailer HD
Comment: @porterwake i don't disagree that a lot of the angles are really similar to each other, but what I DO disagree with is the landscaping. yeah, the book didn't describe that, but what it did describe was where the locations are. Fort Smith is in Arkansas and the Indian Territory is Oklahoma today. when you watch the old movie, you can easily tell that it wasn't shot in locations like those. the new movie was.

Title: 'True Grit' Trailer HD
Comment:
@ryanmacdaddy1000 

And how about the scenes?  They aren't even unique either.  The scenes aren't described in the book, but the new Coen movie used almost ALL the same angles, landscaping, and backgrounds that the book doesn't describe.  It is a copycat movie completely.

Title: 'True Grit' Trailer HD
Comment:
@ryanmacdaddy1000 

I'm well aware of this fact Ryan.  The problem is people are talking like the Coen movie is far more close to the book and so different, but the 1969 and 2010 movie are basically identical.  Sheesh, Bridges draws his inner John Wayne pretty well.....other than the whole napkins in his mouth the whole movie.

Title: 'True Grit' Trailer HD
Comment: @porterwake that's because those scenes are right out of the book. the Coens said they weren't focusing on remaking the old movie. in fact, they thought it sucked balls. they said they were focusing more on adapting the book.

Comment:
@melbea03 - "Your" is possessive.  Ie. "Your YouTube comment".   When attempting to abbreviate "you are," try to remember that the apostrophe always takes the place of something; in this case, the letter "a."  So what you meant to type was, "You're an idiot."  

I'm sure you will remember this in the future.  Here's another example or two:

Aren't  -  the apostrophe takes the place of the "o."

Weren't -  the "o" again.

Comment:
**SPOILER ALERT**
I thought the movie had greater potential if it portrayed the story of Chaney and Ned at the same time. I was kind of left guessing at what type of people they were until we finally met them. I would've also loved to see more shootouts and duels. For a western flick, I thought it had a little too much talking and less shooting, however, the fights were spectacular. All in all, I thought there could've been much more potential for such an immersive movie.

Comment: @fishordie2 It's not a new definition. And Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is not a remake because they didn't base the film off Willy Wonka and the ChocolateÔªø Factory, they  based it on the novel. It's two different things. The 2010 True Grit is an adaptation of the 1968 novel. It's not a remake if the film is being based on a book. It's a new interpretation. A few examples of films that are remakes are Last House on the Left, Nightmare on Elm Street, Halloween, or Assault on Precinct 13

Title: 'True Grit' Trailer HD
Comment: @fishordie2 It would be a remake if they were re-doing the 1969 "True Grit" film. However, this is not the case. The Coen brothers are doing their version of the 1968 "True Grit" novel. It would be like calling "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" a remake of "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory." Just because there both based on the 1964 Roald Dahl novel, "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory," doesn't make the later film adaptation a remake of the earlier film adaptation.

Title: 'True Grit' Trailer HD
Comment: @Theriot6592 - Not everyone...but mustaches were a lot more common, yes.  The reason for this was more than just changing fashion trends, too.  You see, at a time when there was no hot water right from the tap, few varities of pretty-smelling soaps and shaving creams, and nothing but straight razors for the individual to maintain --- NOT having facial hair was a lot of work.  Since the upper lip area usually the most sensitive for "hack job shaving," most men opted to keep the mustache growing.
